body:
Discussed during the biweekly triage meeting. Open to a contributor that can help verify the flake using `stress`. Then, we also want the fix for the flake.

https://github.com/etcd-io/etcd/blob/05d57531e44a398463f929248a8427ea3a295dbe/CONTRIBUTING.md#check-for-flaky-tests

/unassign

I don't think I have the necessary skills to fix this (I tried for the past week with no results). Would love to keep in touch with this issue and whoever will take this up. Thanks!

Hey @ahrtr

I would love to take this up, if you don't mind.
Please assign to me

I've analyzed the flaky `TestPeriodicHourly` test and have implemented a fix that addresses the root cause of the flakiness.

#### Analysis of the Problem

After investigating the issue, I found that the test failure occurs because the test relies on precise timing. In CI environments, timing can be unpredictable, causing the test to fail when actions aren't recorded within the expected 10ms timeout window.

I was able to reliably reproduce the failure by following the instruction from @tjungblu as described in issue #17054, adding an 11ms sleep on line 125 of `periodic.go`. This simulates the slight delays that can occur in CI environments and consistently reproduced the issue.

#### Solution Approach

Rather than simply increasing the timeout (which would slow down the tests), I implemented an exponential backoff retry mechanism. This approach:

1. Attempts to retrieve the actions
2. If unsuccessful, waits for an incrementally longer period 
3. Retries up to a configurable number of times

This maintains fast test execution in the normal case while being robust to occasional timing variations.

#### Validation

I stress-tested the solution with 1000 runs under the artificially constrained conditions (11ms and 100ms delays), and the tests passed consistently. The exponential backoff approach with 5 retries proved to be highly resilient to timing variations between 1 - 200ms. 

Above 200ms on the other hand would fail if 5 retries were the configuration set

I've also applied this approach consistently to all similar test functions that broke while initiating an 11ms sleep 

- TestPeriodicHourly
- TestPeriodicMinutes (failed at 11ms sleep time) 
- TestPeriodicPause (failed at 11ms sleep time) 
- TestPeriodicSkipRevNotChange (failed at 20ms sleep time) 

This should resolve the flakiness while maintaining the test's correctness guarantees.

I will be sending a PR soon so that you can review the code @ahrtr

issue.title: fix(server/etcdserver/api/v3compactor): fix flaky TestPeriodicHourly and others with Retry Mechanism

repository.name: etcd
repository.description: Distributed reliable key-value store for the most critical data of a distributed system

issue.body:
This commit fixes the flaky TestPeriodicHourly test (issue #19499) and similar test cases by introducing an exponential backoff retry mechanism for waiting on actions rather than relying on a fixed timeout.

The root cause of the flakiness was timing inconsistencies in CI environments, where actions sometimes take slightly longer than the expected 10ms timeout set when creating a compactable object.

The new waitWithRetry function attempts to get the expected actions multiple times with exponentially increasing wait periods (10ms, 20ms, 40ms, etc.) before ultimately failing.

The solution was verified by reproducing the issue with an artificial delay and stress-testing the fix with 1000 consecutive runs.

The following test functions were updated to use the new retry mechanism:
- TestPeriodicHourly
- TestPeriodicMinutes
- TestPeriodicPause
- TestPeriodicSkipRevNotChange

Fixes #19499

![test](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/24265bed-4281-4a99-9f98-c6552039f53b)

Please read https://github.com/etcd-io/etcd/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md#contribution-flow.
